hint.details:
Calling (and then returning from) a function prevents many compiler optimizations (like vectorization), breaks control flow (which reduces pipeline performance) and executes extra instructions to save/restore the registers used inside it, which is very expensive (dozens of cycles). Consider to inline small functions.
 - rand@plt: 8 occurrences<<list_path_1_call_1>>
hint.title: CALL instructions

hint.workaround:
Pass to your compiler a micro-architecture specialization option:
 - use march=native
hint.details:
These instructions generate more than one micro-operation and only one of them can be decoded during a cycle and the extra micro-operations increase pressure on execution units.
 - CVTSI2SD: 8 occurrences<<list_path_1_complex_1>>
hint.title: Complex instructions

hint.workaround: Avoid mixing data with different types. In particular, check if the type of constants is the same as array elements.

expert.title: Cycles and memory resources usage
expert.txt:
Assuming all data fit into the L1 cache, each iteration of the binary loop takes 11.60 cycles. At this rate:
 - 4% of peak load performance is reached (5.52 out of 128.00 bytes loaded per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))
 - 8% of peak store performance is reached (5.52 out of 64.00 bytes stored per cycle (GB/s @ 1GHz))

expert.title: Front-end bottlenecks
expert.txt:
Performance is limited by instruction throughput (loading/decoding program instructions to execution core) (front-end is a bottleneck).

By removing all these bottlenecks, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 11.60 to 8.50 cycles (1.36x speedup).

header:
Warnings:
Detected a function call instruction: ignoring called function instructions.
Rerun with --follow-calls=append to include them to analysis  or with --follow-calls=inline to simulate inlining.
2% of peak computational performance is used (0.69 out of 32.00 FLOP per cycle (GFLOPS @ 1GHz))

gain.workaround:
- Try to reorganize arrays of structures to structures of arrays
 - Consider to permute loops (see vectorization gain report)
gain.title: Code clean check
gain.txt:
Detected a slowdown caused by scalar integer instructions (typically used for address computation).
By removing them, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 11.60 to 8.20 cycles (1.41x speedup).

gain.workaround:
- Try another compiler or update/tune your current one:
  * recompile with O2 or higher to enable loop vectorization and with ffast-math (included in Ofast) to extend vectorization to FP reductions.
 - Remove inter-iterations dependences from your loop and make it unit-stride:
  * If your arrays have 2 or more dimensions, check whether elements are accessed contiguously and, otherwise, try to permute loops accordingly:
C storage order is row-major: for(i) for(j) a[j][i] = b[j][i]; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) for(j) a[i][j] = b[i][j]; (fast, stride 1)<<image_row_maj>>
  * If your loop streams arrays of structures (AoS), try to use structures of arrays instead (SoA):
for(i) a[i].x = b[i].x; (slow, non stride 1) => for(i) a.x[i] = b.x[i]; (fast, stride 1)
gain.details:
Store and arithmetical SSE/AVX instructions are used in scalar version (process only one data element in vector registers).
Since your execution units are vector units, only a vectorized loop can use their full power.
gain.title: Vectorization
gain.txt:
Your loop is probably not vectorized.
Only 14% of vector register length is used (average across all SSE/AVX instructions).
By vectorizing your loop, you can lower the cost of an iteration from 11.60 to 1.25 cycles (9.28x speedup).

gain.title: Execution units bottlenecks
gain.txt: Found no such bottlenecks but see expert reports for more complex bottlenecks.
